journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: Theoretical relationships between component design, patient bone geometry and range-of-motion post hip resurfacing

contrib-group.aff: Department of Surgical Sciences, University of Bergen, Norway

author-notes.corresp: Peter Ellison, Department of Surgical Sciences, University of Bergen, Bergen, Norway. Email: Peter.ellison@kir.uib.no

abstract.p: Clinical studies indicate that range of motion until prosthetic impingement is important in understanding unexplained failures of hip resurfacings, yet the underlying biomechanical principles have received little attention. This study investigates the mathematical relationships between component design, position, patient bone geometry and range of motion in hip resurfaced prostheses. Variations in range of motion and impingement-free safe-zones for cup position were calculated using an established method of vector analysis that facilitated parametric analysis in a time efficient manner. The alpha angle, defined as the angle between the centreline of the femoral neck and the waist of the femoral head/neck junction, was used to represent the natural femoral neck. Range of motion and impingement-free safe-zones were inversely proportional to the alpha angle and cup inclusion angle. The size of the safe-zone was most sensitive to the alpha angle with a 6° reduction, decreasing the range of cup positions without impingement by 80–100%. Lowering the upper limit of cup inclination from 55° to 45° reduced the range of cup positions that allow impingement-free motion by 47–94%. No common safe-zone was observed for the range of component sizes and positions investigated. This offers an explanation to why clinic studies have failed to associate outcome with standardised positioning criteria.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Modern metal-on-metal hip resurfacing (HR) arthroplasty has become a popular alternative to total hip replacement (THR) for young adults with arthritis.1,2 However, large scale surveillance studies from arthroplasty registries have found an inferior outcome than reported for conventional treatment.2,3 The position of the acetabular component has been linked to failure2,4–7 although no universal criteria for safe positioning have been identified. It has been proposed that the release of high concentrations of metal ions, through abnormally high wear, leads to adverse inflammatory responses and subsequent failure.4,8 Two identified causes of high wear in metal-on-metal HR are over inclination of the acetabular component and femoroacetabular impingement (FAI),4 both of which result in edge loading of the acetabular component and, subsequently, to increased wear.9,10 FAI is a result of an abnormal shape of the acetabulum, the femoral head or both,11 and as the neck of the femur is retained patients undergoing HR may be more at risk to impingement.

Mathematical formulae defining the technical and theoretical range of motion (ROM) of THR have been presented.12,13 The technical ROM of a hip replacement is the maximum angular displacement between head and cup, being directly proportional to the head/neck ratio and inversely proportional to the cup inclusion angle (CIA).13 In addition to the technical ROM, alignment of the cup and neck dictate the theoretical ROM of the device positioned anatomically. The effect of these parameters on post-operative ROM have been studied for THR allowing theoretical impingement-free safe-zones for cup position to be defined.12–17 Application of these solutions to HR is hindered by the variability of the anatomical head–neck junction and, therefore, prior investigation has relied upon analysis of three-dimensional (3D) solid models,18,19 which is both time and labour intensive. Clinical studies continue to show that ROM post HR could be important in understanding the currently unexplained failures secondary to high blood metal ion levels,1,20 yet investigation of the underlying biomechanical principles are not fully understood and further parametric analyses are needed to understand the designs currently available.

The purpose of this study was to investigate the mathematical relationships between component design and position, patient bone geometry and ROM in HR. In doing so the following hypotheses were tested:

list-item.p: The theoretical ROM post HR is decreased by lowering the upper limit of cup inclination (ULI) from 55° to 45°.
A common impingement-free safe-zone for cup position exists for variations in bearing diameter, neck anterversion and neck shaft angle (NSA) post HR.

sec.title: Materials and method
sec.p: The theoretical ROM post THR is defined by the technical ROM of the device, cup position and neck position. Using vector analysis Yoshimine and Ginbayashi13 defined this relationship mathematically based on five parameters.

list-item.p: Technical ROM (θ), which assuming that the neck cross-section is round and the cup surface is flat, is conical (Figure 1(a)).
The neck angle of the femoral component from the transverse plane (a).

caption.p: (a) Diagram illustrating the technical ROM of a hip prosthesis (θ) where CIA is cup inclusion angle, r is the head radius and n the neck width at the point of impingement. (b) Illustration showing technical-ROM, θ, defined for a HR prosthesis. The point of impingement is defined from the waist of the femoral head–neck junction, termed the alpha angle (α).

Position of the acetabular cup and femoral head for a left hip. (a) Acetabular cup and a cone indicating the technical ROM, θ. Cup position is defined using cup inclination, δ, and cup anteversion, β. (b) Hip prosthesis indicating the orientation of the femoral neck, a, the angle of the neck axis to the transverse plane, and b, neck anteversion.

sec.p: This analysis results in a system of equations that allows theoretical ROM for THR to be calculated directly in a simple and accurate manner, thereby facilitating parametric analysis.

In this study, the Yoshimine–Ginbayashi equations have been applied to HRs. As the femoral neck is not part of a HR prosthesis, it was necessary to adapt the approach to include a parameter defining the width of the femoral neck at the point where it impinges on the edge of the cup (Figure 1(b)). This was achieved by use of the alpha angle (α), defined as the angle between the centreline of the femoral neck and the waist of the femoral head–neck junction. Therefore, when the head and neck are aligned concentrically the head/neck ratio can be calculated from the alpha angle (Figure 1(b))
As technical ROM can be shown to be
It follows that

Component geometries of two commercially available HR designs were obtained by measuring production implants and X-ray templates; these designs were chosen based on material available to the author. For each design, the variation in CIA with bearing diameter was used to calculate the technical ROM over that size range. The mean CIA and technical ROM of the two designs were then calculated. Designs are presented in terms of technical ROM to allow the reader a normalised reference by which comparisons to other designs of HR and THR can be made.

Impingement-free safe-zones presented as a function of cup position, using the radiographic definition of δ and β, were calculated for a number of different configurations of HR device and patient geometry. The safe-zone was defined as that able to provide:

list-item.p: internal rotation at 90° FL (IRfl90) of more than 30°;

extension (EXT) of more than 30°.This follows the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons and Japanese Orthopedic Association recommendations12 and has been reported as moderate criteria of acceptable ROM needed for activities of daily living (ADL).14 Two additional ROM conditions previously suggested as severe criteria were also considered, being:

sec.p: Motion before impingement was calculated for each of the criteria using the mathematical formulae previously presented by Yoshimine and Ginbayashi,13 these equations are reproduced in Appendix 2. Lastly, an upper limit of inclination (ULI) of 55° was specified as a criterion beyond which impingement-free cup positions were disregarded.
Safe-zone size was quantified in units of (°)2 and compared to the safe-zone of Lewinnek et al.,21 being cup inclination of 30–50° and anteversion of 5–25° and having an area of 127 (°)2.

sec.title: Influence of bearing diameter and alpha angle
sec.p: Safe-zones were calculated for 40, 50 and 60 mm bearing diameters at alpha angles of 43° and 37°. An alpha angle of 43° was chosen as it is the average reported for a healthy hip22,23 and an alpha angle of 37° represented the mean value post resurfacing.24 Throughout these calculations the position of the neck was held constant, with a and b maintained at 54° and 12°, respectively.

sec.title: Influence of ULI
sec.p: The prior analyses were re-run using an ULI of 45° and 55° in order to investigate the effect of inclination angle on the size and shape of the impingement-free safe-zone.

sec.title: Common safe-zone
sec.p: The effect of NSA and neck anterversion on the size and location of the safe-zone was investigated. Safe-zones for the moderate criteria for ADL were calculated for 40, 50 and 60 mm bearing diameters at neck anteversions of 0°, 10° and 20°, with NSAs of 138° and 133°. A common safe-zone for the range of neck anteversions was calculated for each bearing diameter and NSA. For these analyses the alpha angle was held constant at 37°, and a varied from 54° to 49° for NSAs of 138° and 133°, respectively. Variation in the neck angle to the transverse plane was a function of NSA and neck anteversion as inherently defined by the geometry of the hip.12

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The range of CIAs of the two designs varied from 156° to 166°, and was directly proportional to bearing diameter (Figure 3). The function representing the mean CIA was
Where φHead is bearing diameter. Substituting equation (4) into equation (3) we can show that the mean technical ROM is equal to

caption.p: CIA for two commercially available HR devices as a function of head diameter.

sec.p: Technical ROM was inversely proportional to the bearing diameter, with design B being approximately 4° greater than that of design A across the range of bearing diameters investigated (Figure 4).

caption.p: Technical-ROM for two commercially available HR devices as a function of head diameter. The calculation was made using an alpha angle of 37°.

sec.title: Influence of bearing diameter and alpha angle
sec.p: The impingement-free safe-zones calculated for 40, 50 and 60 mm bearing diameters at alpha angles of 37° and 43° are shown in Figure 5. In each case the upper limit of the safe-zone is defined by two concave lines with a negative slope representing FL110 and IRfl9030. The lower limit of the safe-zones are defined by two convex lines, representing ER40 and EXT30. The size of the safe-zone reduced with increasing bearing diameter and alpha angle (Table 1). No cup position satisfied the severe criteria for ADL at an alpha angle of 43° (Figure 5(d) and (e)). There was no safe-zone for either moderate or severe criteria with a bearing diameter of 60 mm and an alpha angle of 43° (Figure 5(f)).

caption.p: Impingement-free safe-zones for 40, 50 and 60 mm diameter bearings at alpha angles (α) of 37° and 43°, when the neck angle of the femoral component from the transverse plane (a) was 54° and neck anteversion (b) was 12°. The total shaded and lightly shaded areas represent the values of cup anteversion (β) and cup inclination (δ) that meet the moderate and severe criteria for ADL, respectively. (a) θ = 127.4°, (b) θ = 123.67°, (c) θ = 119.95°, (d) θ = 115.4°, (e) θ = 111.67°, (f) θ = 107.95°.
Impingement-free safe-zones for moderate and severe criteria for ADL with bearing diameters of 40, 50 and 60 mm; ULI of 55° and 45°; and alpha angle (α) of 37° and 43°.

fn.p: ULI: upper limit of cup inclination; ADL: activities of daily living.

sec.title: ULI
sec.p: Impingement free safe-zones calculated with a ULI of 55° and 45° are shown in Figure 6. Bearing diameters varied from 40 to 60 mm and alpha angles from 37° to 43°. Lowering the ULI by 10° reduced the size of the safe-zones by 47–94% depending on the combination of alpha angle and bearing diameter (Table 1, Figure 6). The largest reductions were observed for smaller bearing diameters. There was no safe-zone for an alpha angle of 43° under the severe criteria for ADL.

caption.p: Effect of ULI on the impingement-free safe-zones for the moderate and severe criteria for ADL. Differences were calculated for bearing diameters of 40, 50 and 60 mm at alpha angles (α) of 37° and 43°. The neck angle of the femoral component from the transverse plane (a) was 54° and neck anteversion (b) was 12°.
ADL: activities of daily living; ULI: upper limit of inclination.

sec.title: Common safe-zone
sec.p: Safe-zones calculated for neck anteversion angles of 0°–20°, with a NSA of 138° and bearing diameters of 40 to 60 mm, are shown in Figure 7(a)–(c), respectively. Similarly, those calculated for a NSA of 133° are shown in Figures 7(d)–(f). Safe-zone area increased with neck anteversion for any constant configuration of bearing diameter and NSA, with the rate of increase being greater for smaller diameter bearings (Table 2). Reducing the NSA had a small impact on the size and position of the safe-zone. For a constant bearing diameter, reducing NSA decreased the safe-zone area with neck anteversions of 0° and 10°. For a neck anteversion of 20° the safe-zone area, at a constant bearing diameter, increased when the NSA increased. The size of the common safe-zone was proportional to the NSA, but inversely proportional to bearing diameter. There were no common safe-zones for a bearing diameter of 60 mm at either NSA (Figure 7(c) and (f)).

caption.p: Impingement-free safe-zones for moderate criteria for ADL with a variation in neck anterversion of the femoral component, b, and NSA. In all cases alpha angle (α) was 37°. The centroid of each common safe-zone is marked with a cross. No common safe-zone was observed for the configurations shown in Figures (c) and (f).

Impingement-free safe-zones for moderate criteria for ADL using bearing diameters of 40, 50 and 60 mm; neck anteversion (b) of 0°, 10° and 20°; NSA of 138° and 133°. The alpha angle was held constant at 37° during all calculations.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Edge loading owing to impingement is one potential mechanism that can lead to accelerated wear of a HR.4 For THR the relationship between technical ROM and component design is governed by the CIA of the acetabular cup and the head/neck ratio of the femoral component. As the femoral neck is not part of a HR prosthesis an estimate of the width of the patients femoral neck, at the point where it impinges on the edge of the cup, must be included when calculating the technical ROM. The approach presented in this study adapted the method of Yoshimine and Ginbayashi13 method to HR, allowing some of the fundamental relationships between component design, patient bone geometry and ROM to be investigated through parametric analysis.

For the two commercially available designs of HR analysed, CIA, and, therefore, technical ROM was inversely proportional to the bearing diameter (Figures 3 and 4). Further, for a fixed CIA, the coefficient of the alpha angle2 was greater than the coefficient of the bearing diameter (0.37), indicating a larger effect upon the technical ROM (equation (5)). This provides a mathematical explanation for the surgical observation that the head/neck offset should be maximised in order to minimise impingement.6,15,20 Assuming an alpha angle of 37° the technical ROM for the designs investigated varied from 120° to 130° (Figure 4). While this is within the reported range for THR (100°–130°) it is below the recommended value of 135° resulting from extensive theoretical analysis.12,13,17 The dependence of ROM on the alpha angle is especially important as large alpha angles are synonymous with FAI, which is recognised to be a precursor to osteoarthritis of the hip11 and, therefore, likely to be present in patients undergoing HR. For reference, values of alpha angle reported for patients with FAI range from 42°–95°.22,23

sec.title: Influence of bearing diameter and alpha angle
sec.p: The impingement-free safe-zones for cup position were not square and are generally located at higher angles of inclination and anteversion than the Lewinnek safe-zone (Figure 5). The size of the safe-zone was proportional to the technical ROM and, therefore, more sensitive to alpha angle than the CIA by an order of magnitude, as already discussed. Alpha angle had a considerable effect on the size of the safe-zone, with a 6° reduction reducing it from between 80% and 100%.

The inverse relationship between bearing diameter and safe-zone area may appear counter intuitive considering that, clinically, elevated blood metal ion levels that are presumed to be a result of abnormal wear, or edge loading, have been associated with small bearing diameters.25 However, simulator studies have shown that wear of smaller diameter bearings is higher,26 and that wear increases by a greater amount in smaller diameter bearings than larger diameters with increases in cup inclination and the presence of micro-separation.9,27 Therefore, although smaller bearings are less likely to impinge their wear rate appears to be more affected than larger diameter bearings.

At an alpha angle of 37° and a ULI of 55° the moderate safe-zone for bearing diameters of 40–60 mm covered between one half and one quarter of that suggested by Lewinnek et al.21 (Figure 6(a)). The severe criteria for ADL reduced the cup positions where no impingement occurred, such that less that 4% of the Lewinnek safe-zone was covered in all cases. For all configurations of alpha angle and bearing diameter the reduction in relative safe-zone area when changing from moderate to severe criteria was between 66% and 100%. These findings are in agreement with the general outcome of a previous computer-aided design (CAD)-based study that the ROM post HR is typically low.18 Further, it highlights that the range of impingement-free cup positions offering high ROM are greatly reduced.

sec.title: ULI
sec.p: Cup inclination higher than 55° has been associated with increased contact stress at the bearing surface,9,15 increased wear rates10 and higher serum levels of metal ions.25 However, a HR cup with a CIA of less than 180° positioned at 45° inclination will have a smaller centre edge angle than a typical THR,which are near hemispherical or greater. This has prompted the suggestion that HR devices should be implanted at reduced inclinations to achieve a centre-edge angle equivalent to a typical THR design.7

The theoretical analysis presented here shows that the safe-zone area was reduced as the ULI was reduced from 55° to 45°, with larger percentage reductions for larger bearing diameters (Table 1). The reduction in safe-zone area was greater than 47% in all configurations of alpha angle and bearing diameter. Therefore, the hypothesis that the theoretical ROM post HR is decreased by lowering the ULI from 55° to 45° was accepted. Thus, while the theory that lowering the target inclination angle compensates for a reduced centre-edge angle, it has the counter effect of substantially increasing the range of cup positions where impingement occurs.

sec.title: Common safe-zone
sec.p: Previous clinical studies for the placement of HR devices predominately focus on the positioning of the cup. As shown for THR,16,17 it is important to recognise that the position of the head influences the size and position of the impingement-free safe-zone. Lowering the NSA reduced the size of the common safe-zone for all bearing diameters investigated, with the absolute reductions being largest for smaller bearings (Table 2, Figure 7). This may explain the association between low NSA and poor outcome following HR reported clinically.24,28

The combined effect of neck anteversion, NSA and bearing diameter was investigated through calculation of common safe-zones. The size of the common safe-zone was proportional to the size of the individual safe-zones and, therefore, inversely proportional to bearing diameter (Table 2). There were no common safe-zones for a 60 mm bearing diameter at either NSA (Figure 7) and, therefore, the hypothesis that a common impingement-free safe-zone for cup position exists across the clinically relevant range of variations in bearing diameter, neck anterversion and NSA post HR was rejected. This helps to explain why attempts to associate clinical wear rates with a standardised safe-zone have not been successful.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: Two additional parameters that should be recognised when defining a safe-zone for cup position are the rotation of the inclination–anteversion plane about the vertical axis and the variation in pelvic tilt between, and during, activities. The rotation of the inclination–anteversion plane is not generally considered in the definition of positioning guides for HR devices, but is necessary in order to locate the cup precisely in 3D space. This parameter was included in the methodology presented by the head position, b, which accounts for the relative location of the head relative to the cup. The variation in pelvic tilt was not investigated in this study but is likely to influence the size and position of the safe-zone during use.

A further limitation of the model was that it did not account for the out-of-roundness of the head–neck junction. The cross-section of the head–neck junction is not circular,22 and the alpha angle varies radially around the femoral neck axis. The values of alpha angle used in this study were observed in the anterior region and, therefore, the predictions are likely to underestimate EXT and ER movement before impingement.

Finally it must be noted that the model did not account for bone–bone or soft tissue impingement. In both of these cases the available ROM decreases so that the possibility of edge loading owing to impingement becomes greater.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study has investigated the mathematical relationships between component design, position, patient bone geometry and ROM in HR prostheses. This allows a clearer understanding of functional attributes of existing HR designs and, therefore, will facilitate analysis and development of improved designs of hip prostheses. From this study the following conclusions can be drawn.

list-item.p: For the commercially available designs investigated, ROM is inversely proportional to bearing diameter.

ROM and the cup impingement-free safe-zone are more sensitive to femoral bone geometry (alpha angle) than implant design. For the configurations investigated a 6° reduction reduced the range of cup positions in the safe-zone by 80% to 100%.
Reducing the target ULI from 55° to 45° reduces the range of cup positions that meet moderate criteria for ADL by 47 to 94%.
Theoretically, a common impingement-free safe-zone does not exist and, therefore, it is unlikely one exists for HR under clinic conditions.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: a neck angle of the femoral component from the transverse plane
A cup opening angle
b neck anteversion
n neck width at the point of impingement
r head radius
α alpha angle, defined as the angle between the centreline of the femoral neck and the waist of the femoral head–neck junction
β cup anteversion
δ cup inclination
θ technical ROM

φ
Head bearing diameter

sec.title: Abbreviations
sec.p: ADL activities of daily living
CAD computer-aided design
CIA cup inclusion angle
ER external rotation
ER40 external rotation of more than 40°
EXT extension
EXT30 extension of more than 30°
FAI femoroacetabular impingement
FL flexion
FL110 flexion of more than 110°
HR hip resurfacing
IR internal rotation
IRfl90 internal rotation at a flexion of 90°
IRfl9030 internal rotation at a flexion of 90° of more than 30°
NSA neck shaft angle
ROM range of motion
THR total hip replacement
ULI upper limit of cup inclination
